pullRequest.body:
I've copied the API from `Subring`, but some proofs from there don't work here due to `Ideal.map` including an extra `Ideal.span`.

---

nodes.body:
### PR summary [690e87cf76](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/13294/commits/690e87cf76bde2ac48c4b26eea3a3025d1208192)

#### Import changes

No significant changes to the import graph

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ instance : CovariantClass M (Ideal R) HSMul.hSMul LE.le`
`+ mem_inv_pointwise_smul_iff`
`+ mem_pointwise_smul_iff_inv_smul_mem`
`+ pointwiseMulSemiringAction`
`+ pointwise_central_scalar`
`+ pointwise_smul_def`
`+ pointwise_smul_eq_comap`
`+ pointwise_smul_le_pointwise_smul_iff`
`+ pointwise_smul_subset_iff`
`+ pointwise_smul_toAddSubGroup`
`+ pointwise_smul_toAddSubmonoid`
`+ smul_bot`
`+ smul_closure`
`+ smul_mem_pointwise_smul`
`+ smul_mem_pointwise_smul_iff`
`+ smul_sup`
`+ subset_pointwise_smul_iff`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh short <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh <optional_commit>
```
</details>

</details>

As far as I am concerned this is ready, modulo the fact that Yael moved various files from RingTheory into Alegebra/Ring, so my one remaining question is whether the file in this PR should be called `Mathlib/Algebra/Ring/Ideal/Pointwise.lean` (and I think Yael is out of commission for the next week or two).

Thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9762660224/job/26946657195)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9762660224/job/26946658153)

This file doesn't seem to exist. Do you mean `Algebra/Ring/Subsemiring/Pointwise.lean`? I was going to say "you might want to put a note in that file suggesting that it be kept in sync with this one", but then I looked at that file and there's already a note saying that it should be kept in sync with a third file, which also doesn't seem to exist.
I think @YaelDillies moved all the files around, but the comments were left with the old names.
My regex assumed files were referred to as `A.B.C`, not `A/B/C` 😐
OK but just to be clear: purely for the purposes of reviewing this PR, which file am I supposed to be checking that it's similar to?
Wherever you see a missing file, try replacing `RingTheory` by `Algebra.Ring`
And `GroupTheory/Submonoid/Pointwise.lean` (mentioned in the subsemiring file) -> `Algebra/Group/Submonoid/Pointwise.lean` presumably? Currently fixing all this up.
So should the file in this PR be called `Mathlib/Algebra/Ring/Ideal/Pointwise.lean`?

Perhaps it should be called that in a future PR, but for now the important thing is that it lives next to `RingTheory/Ideal/Basic.lean`, which is where I have it now. If @YaelDillies  wants to move all of the files somewhere else in a later PR I'm happy to stay out of their way!

```suggestion
  smul a I := I.map (MulSemiringAction.toRingHom _ _ a)
```
is there a reason you went for the more longwinded spelling?

Furthermore, using comap on a^{-1} for the definition works much better definitionally in the case where M is a group. I'm just moving from my own implementation to this and noticing this annoyance. Monoids can act by endomorphisms; groups have to act via automorphisms. We have to sacrifice nice definitional properties just because we want some generalization to monoids which in practice mathematicians may never use? :-(

> Furthermore, using comap on a^{-1} for the definition works much better definitionally in the case where M is a group.

The same could be said for pretty much all the pointwise actions - I took the map approach here mainly for consistency.

> We have to sacrifice nice definitional properties just because we want some generalization to monoids which in practice mathematicians may never use? :-(

This already happened with the definition of `Disjoint`, and surprisingly I haven't really noticed anyone complaining...

> just because we want some generalization to monoids which in practice mathematicians may never use?

Maybe `MulSemiringAction` is to blame here for being unreasonably general; are there any examples of such actions which are a monoid action and not a group action?
Probably the endomorphisms of a commutative ring act on the ideals of the ring and I could imagine that someone might need that.
Is there a reason you used `_a₁` and not just `_`?
Yes, to make the goal view easier to understand. It seems the linter no longer requires the `_`s though.

It's true for group actions though, right? Should it be in the `Group` part of the file? Similar comment for `Subring.coe_pointwise_smul`.

This observation is perhaps an indication that the correct definition for monoids is to use comap and let them act on the right? But I'm not advocating for this!
I added a weaker version.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: add pointwise actions on ideals
